title: Australian Pharma warns of soft consumer sentiment
text:
Revenue for the year ended August 31 were up marginally, adding 0.4 per cent to $4 billion. Earnings before interest and tax (EBIT) jumped 14.1 per cent to $94 million.

Reported net profit after tax gained 17.4 per cent to $56.6 million but on an underlying basis it was up just 0.8 per cent to $55.1 million due to $6.6 million in costs associated with acquisitions and restructuring hitting fiscal 2018 results.

Priceline like-for-like sales were up just 0.7 per cent for the full year. The chain returned to positive like-for-like sales growth for the first time in two years in the first half, which continued into the second half. Network sales for the period were up 2.4 per cent to $2.2 billion.

API continued to target its Sister Club loyalty program customers, which, it says, have a 34 per cent higher basket size than non-members.

The Priceline Pharmacy store network grew by a net 13 stores during the year to 488 stores. It reduced he number of company owned stores by seven during the year.

“We expect that performance during the year will initially be determined by the sales through the Christmas trading period and, in the longer term, resolution of the 7th Community Pharmacy Agreement negotiations remains important,” Mr Vincent said.

Mr Vincent said he expects the CSO structure to be maintained and to provide earnings guidance at API's January AGM.

Pharmacy Distribution revenue growth - excluding Hepatitis C sales and PBS reform impacts - increased 4.2 per cent to $2.9 billion. Taking into account the lower sales of Hepatitis C due to the successful treatment of the disease, and a decrease in demand for the medicine, pushed sales down 1.9 per cent over the year.

Advertisement

With revenue growth of more than 30 per ent in its consumer brands business, Mr Vincent said this continues to be a major source of expansion for API.

"Throughout the year we saw growth in our expanded healthcare range and personal care category, and we introduced, among other products, a new range of vitamins," he said.

Mr Vincent said growth opportunities remain strong from new Clear Skincare clinics' new offerings and broadening distribution of the product range. Revenue reached $45.6 million, up 20 per cent over the year.

He said that API continued to leverage its existing infrastructure and market expertise to deliver solid profit growth for shareholders in what remains a challenging market.

“Our core businesses performed to expectations, with Priceline Pharmacy reporting improving like-for-like sales growth throughout the year and Pharmacy Distribution holding market share in a competitive environment," he said.

"We have bedded down our Clear Skincare acquisition whilst expanding the network to 52 clinics, from 44 this time last year. Our Consumer Brands business expanded further, and we continue to be excited about its prospects.

Mr Vincent said API continues to review its strategic holding in rival Sigma Healthcare, which knocked back its takeover overtures last March.

API is Sigma's largest shareholder, controlling almost 13 per cent of the company.

A final dividend of 4¢ per share was declared and taking total dividends for the year to 7.75¢, a 3.3 per cent increase on prior period. Payment date is December 12.
description: The $724 million owner of pharmacy chain, Priceline, says that performance during this new year will be partially determined by pending Christmas trade.
